inputFields.description:
This argument accepts a string specifying a duration.
It takes a succession of a number (positive integer) and a time unit, one of:
s[econd[s]], m[inute[s]], h[our[s]], d[ay[s]], w[eek[s]], mo[nth[s]].
Number/unit pairs can be contiguous or separated by spaces.
Valid examples: "3d4h" "11 minutes" "2month", "1s", "12 second"
If not provided, target is banned permanently.

types.name: ChatMessage

types.description: Reasons that a user might not be allowed to chat in a specific channel.

enumValues.description:
The user is prevented from chatting by subscribers-only mode. They should
subscribe to the channel to chat.
enumValues.name: SUBSCRIBERS_ONLY

enumValues.description:
The user is prevented from chatting by followers-only mode. They should
either follow the channel, or wait longer to satisfy the required time.
See user.self.follower.followedAt for when the user followed, and
user.self.chatSettings.followersOnlyDurationMinutes for the minimum
required follow time.
enumValues.name: FOLLOWERS_ONLY

enumValues.description:
The user is prevented from chatting by verified-only mode. They should
verify their account to chat.
enumValues.name: VERIFIED_ONLY

enumValues.description:
The user can't chat because they've chatted too recently. See
user.self.lastRecentChatMessageAt to calculate how much time is remaining
before they can chat again.
enumValues.name: SLOW_MODE

emotes are the metadata about the different cheermotes that can be use to cheer in this channel.

will be applied to the result unless it's null or empty.
If includeUpperTiers is true, the upper tiers of the cheermotes will be returned.

enumValues.description: Third Party Cheermotes, like Muxy and BitBoss.

we decided this is better than erroring the whole response, the front end should treat this the same as DISPLAY_ONLY.

types.description:
Deprecated

An event represents a piece of scheduled content.  Events allow broadcasters to advertise their content
before it happens.  All events:

  * ... are routeable.  Each event has a URL that can be shared off-site.  The URL will usually resolve to a
    landing page that has information on the event, and content that happened during the event.
  * ... can be followed by Twitch users.  When a user follows an event, they get notifications on when the
    event goes live.

The Event interface is the common set of fields that all events support.  There are several concrete Event types
that represent different kinds of scheduled content.  The kinds of content include one-off events, premieres,
tournaments, conferences and panels, shows and episodes etc.
The concrete Event types include additional fields that are needed to describe their kind of content.

NOTE: Clients should be resilient to new concrete types being added in the future.

NOTE: Events have been designed here using polymorphic types.
This is a (mostly) untested design pattern for API types, and we are currently learning about its advantages
and disadvantages.
Teams are encouraged to avoid polymorphic types and design their types to use composition instead, if possible.

fields.name: owner

fields.name: self

fields.name: stats

fields.description: When this event was last modified.
fields.name: updatedAt

types.name: DropAward

types.description:
A campaign a developer is running to give drops away to viewers of their game
To be considered live, a campaign must be enabled with the current time
being after the start but before the end times
To apply to a particular channel a campaign must be live and additionally
the channel must be playing an applicable game and either must be one of the
applicable channels or the campaign must have an empty applicable channel list
(where an empty list specifically means all channels are eligible).

types.description:
An event represents a piece of scheduled content.  Events allow broadcasters to advertise their content
before it happens.  All events:

  * ... are routeable.  Each event has a URL that can be shared off-site.  The URL will usually resolve to a
    landing page that has information on the event, and content that happened during the event.
  * ... can be followed by Twitch users.  When a user follows an event, they get notifications on when the
    event goes live.

There are currently two high-level categories of events.  EventLeaf, which is a single event that may or may
not be part of a collection, or an EventCollection that groups leaves together.
types.name: Event

inputFields.description:
Defines the strategies that are used to determine where the first page of events should start within the complete
list of events.  Moving forwards or backwards past this first page is possible using standard Relay pagination.
The options are processed in order, and if an option cannot be fulfilled (e.g. if the first option states to
start at a particular ID, but the ID does not exist in the list), then the next option is considered.
If no options can be fulfilled, or no options are given, the first page will start at the first event
after sorting and ordering.
inputFields.name: firstPageOptions

inputFields.description:
Select for events that involve at least one game that corresponds to the given game IDs.  If left unspecified,
no filtering by game is done.

types.description: The possible values for ExtensionState.

enumValues.description: IN_TEST extensions are currently being worked on by a developer.
enumValues.name: IN_TEST

enumValues.description:
READY_FOR_REVIEW extensions are currently being examined by a developer for their readiness
to be reviewed (assets hosted on CDN).
enumValues.name: READY_FOR_REVIEW

enumValues.description: IN_REVIEW extensions are being looked at by Twitch.
enumValues.name: IN_REVIEW

enumValues.description: REJECTED extensions are permanently rejected; no action by the  developer will make them acceptable.
enumValues.name: REJECTED

enumValues.description: APPROVED extensions are ready to be released, at the developer's convenience.
enumValues.name: APPROVED

enumValues.description:
RELEASED extensions are currently available to users.  Only one version of an extension
can be in this state at any time.
enumValues.name: RELEASED

enumValues.description: DEPRECATED extensions were once released, but a newer version now exists.
enumValues.name: DEPRECATED

enumValues.description: PENDING_ACTION extensions are ones that were reviewed by Twitch and returned to the developer for fixing.
enumValues.name: PENDING_ACTION

enumValues.description: UPLOADING extensions are in the process of having their assets loaded onto S3.
enumValues.name: UPLOADING

enumValues.description:
ASSETS_UPLOADED extensions have had their assets uploaded already to S3. This state mirrors
the existing READY_FOR_REVIEW state, but doesn't incur an implicit upload.
enumValues.name: ASSETS_UPLOADED

enumValues.description: DELETED extensions have been deleted; this is a soft delete so we can undelete things.
enumValues.name: DELETED

types.description:
The friend-type relationship between the authenticated user and another user.

If this field is a FriendEdge, the authenticated user and the other user are Friends.

If it is an IncomingFriendRequestEdge, the other user has an open friend request with authenticated user.

If it is an OutgoingFriendRequestEdge, the authenticated user has an open friend request with the other user.

The languages param can be used to filter the streams. Otherwise all languages will be returned.
The filters param contains additional metadata filters, for example {hearthstoneGameMode: "arena"}.
The sort param can be used to change the default sorting, which sometimes is specific to specific games.
The tags param are an array of tag ID as optional filters for streams.

Use GameStreamOptions instead.

Defines the strategies that are used to determine where the first page of events should start within the complete
list of events.  Moving forwards or backwards past this first page is possible using standard Relay pagination.
The options are processed in order, and if an option cannot be fulfilled (e.g. if the first option states to
start at a particular ID, but the ID does not exist in the list), then the next option is considered.
If no options can be fulfilled, or no options are given, the first page will start at the first event
after sorting and ordering.

types.description:
Milestone is a construct is used within a tournament. For a given threshold, when the user 
cheers at or past this amount, they are able to claim a reward for cheering at this level.
Rewards can be fulfilled by different platforms.
Types of milestones:
- **Global milestone**: for a given threshold, this milestone is reached when cheers from all 
  users on the channel is greater than or equal to the threshold. 
  This unlocks a reward for all users who have cheered.
- **Individual milestone**: for a given threshold, this milestone is reached when an individual 
  user's total cheers in the channel is greater than or equal to the threshold. 
  This unlocks a reward for the individual user who cheered.
- **Team milestone**: for a given threshold, this milestone is reached when an individual cheers 
  for a specific team in total is greater than or equal to the threshold. 
  This unlocks a reward for the individual user who cheered.

NOTE: Should have been named CheeringTournamentMilestone.

fields.description: End date for when a milestone is no longer active.

fields.description: GraphQL ID of the milestone.

fields.name: isPrimeOnly

fields.name: objectiveTag

fields.description: Threshold that needs to be cheered by an individual to claim reward.
fields.name: participationThreshold

fields.description: The rewards associated with milestones.
fields.name: rewards

fields.description: Start date for when a milestone is active.
fields.name: startDate

fields.description: Threshold that needs to be cheered to claim reward.
fields.name: threshold

fields.description: acceptFriendRequest accepts a friend request from the target user to the authenticated user, creating a new Friend relationship.

fields.description:
addBrowserPushSubscription adds a browser push subscription for receiving browser (desktop) push notifications.
The client must retrieve the input fields from the browser's push notification API. Client's will
call this when the user opts-in. A browser push subscription is tied to a user's browser (device).
Twitch will use these push subscriptions to send browser push notifications.

Spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/push-api/#push-subscription.
fields.name: addBrowserPushSubscription

types.description: OEmbed is a universal spec converted to GraphQL from http://oembed.com/.

type with required parameters.

types.description: Current state of the user in the onboarding process.

fields.description:
Retrieves a list of streams that have been selected for onboarding based on a user's followed games.
`first` is the number of streams PER FOLLOWED GAME to fetch.
`locale` is a language code that will filter streams by if there are viewers with that language code (ex. "en-US", "es-ES", or "de-AT").
`languages` is list of language codes that will be used to filter streams by the broadcaster language. (ex. [EN, KO]).
`games` are a list of game ids that would replace the user's followed games for fetching the streams.
fields.name: onboardingStreams

fields.description: List of channel IDs skipped by a user during onboarding.
fields.name: skippedChannelIDs

types.description:
PurchaseToken is a token that appears in the chat, specific to 
a tuid/channel (i.e. if a customer buys a product, we give them the option of 
sharing it in the channel they bought it from).

fields.description:
asin is the purchased Amazon ASIN (a unique identifier for products at 
Amazon) to be shared.
fields.name: asin

fields.description:
badges is the set of badges to be shared.  There may be duplicate badges
associated with the same token.
fields.name: badges

fields.description: bits is the set of bits to be shared.
fields.name: bits

fields.description: crateCount is the number of crates associated with the purchase.
fields.name: crateCount

fields.description:
emoteSets is the set of emote sets to be shared.  There may be duplicate
emote sets associated with the same token.
fields.name: emoteSets

fields.description: id is the unique message identifier.
fields.name: id

fields.description:
imageURL is the URL for the image to be used for the purchase token.
An optional width can be specified to return an image of the given width. If
no size is specified the images native size will be used.
fields.name: imageURL

fields.description: In game content is the in game content to be shared.
fields.name: inGameContents

fields.description: status is the status of the purchase token.
fields.name: status

fields.description: timeReceived is the time the chat token token was created.
fields.name: timeReceived

fields.description: title is the title to be used for the purchase token.
fields.name: title

fields.description: token is the consumable purchase token.
fields.name: token

fields.description:
Fetch directories in specified sort order, optionally filtered to the specified type.
Filters are additive, meaning that using two filters will include results from both types.
An empty filter list implies that no filters are applied, hence all results are included regardless of type.
By default returns 10, sorted by descending total viewer count, unfiltered.

the released version of that extension is returned.

fields.description:
Fetch a paginated list of Extension Categories. Each Category will provide the first ten
extensions sorted by popularity in that category.
fields.name: extensionCategories

fields.description: Fetch a single category. Both slugs and ids are valid inputs for getting a category.
fields.name: extensionCategory

fields.description:
Search extensions by text found in the Extension name, description or summary. The results are
always returned in order of popularity. By default, all RELEASED and IN_TEST extensions are returned.
Pass RELEASED as the value of 'state' to only return extensions in the RELEASED state.
fields.name: extensions

By default returns 6 streams.

redeemed to send the announcement in a channel.

types.description:
Describes the role a user must be in order to perform an action, such as sending messages. Roles are
hierarchical, so users that meet a role also meet all lower roles as well. For example, a moderator
meets the subscriber role, even if they are not subscribed to the channel. Roles are defined in order
from highest to lowest in the enum.

enumValues.name: MODERATOR

enumValues.description: A subscriber of the channel.

enumValues.description: All users.
enumValues.name: EVERYONE

types.description:
Segment events are sub-events that represent a piece of content that is part of a greater event.
SegmentEvent would be good at representing:
  * A single run of a gaming event like "Awesome Games Done Quick 2017".  These segments could be children
    under a TimetableEvent which would group all the runs for "Awesome Games Done Quick 2018" together.
  * A single panel in a conference like "TwitchCon 2017".  These segments could be children
    under a TimetableEvent which would group all the panels for the conference together.

fields.description: The channel where this event will be broadcast.
fields.name: channel

fields.description: When this event was created.
fields.name: createdAt

fields.description: The description of this event.
fields.name: description

fields.description: The time that this event ends.
fields.name: endAt

fields.description: The game that will be played during this event.
fields.name: game

fields.description: The Event's unique identifier.
fields.name: id

fields.description: The chosen image ID for this event.
fields.name: imageID

fields.description:
The URL or a URL template to the cover image for this event.
An optional width and height can be given to specify the dimension of the image in pixels.
If left unspecified, this field will be a URL template with {width} and {height} placeholders
that the client can replace to create a functional URL.
When width and height are given, this field is a full URL to the image.
The image is first scaled to maintain its aspect ratio, then cropped to fit the given dimensions.
fields.name: imageURL

fields.description: The language that this event is being run in.
fields.name: language

fields.description: The user who owns this event.
fields.name: owner

fields.description: The container event that this event is a part of.
fields.name: parent

fields.description: The authenticated user's relationship with this event.
fields.name: self

fields.description: The time that this event starts.
fields.name: startAt

fields.description: The stats about engagement with this event.
fields.name: stats

fields.description: The title of this event.
fields.name: title

fields.description: When this event was last modified.
fields.name: updatedAt

fields.description:
Highlights or past broadcasts recorded during this event.
If a type isn't specified, both broadcasts and highlights will be included in the list.
If sort isn't specified, the list will be sorted by start time, in descending order.
fields.name: videos

types.description:
SetSessionStatusInput represents a user's status within a single session (browser tab, game, desktop application,
mobile application, etc.).

inputFields.description:
activity is the action the user is performing in your application. The purpose of an activity is to allow the user's
friends and related users to join in on whatever the user is doing. If the user is not performing any action that
other users can join in on (e.g. watching a VOD, browsing their settings page) or is not performing any action at
all, this should be set to null.
inputFields.name: activity

inputFields.description:
availability is the state of the user's session in your application. You should set it to ONLINE if the user is
known to be at their device, IDLE if they are not, and OFFLINE if your application is currently terminating.

Note that if your application fails to send an OFFLINE heartbeat before terminating, the session will automatically
expire after some time without a heartbeat.
inputFields.name: availability

inputFields.description:
sessionID must be supplied and can be any string unique to this session. Generating a random UUID when your
application starts and sending it for each setSessionStatus is a good idea.

Each instance of your application should send the same ID for each of its setSessionStatus calls, but two instances
of your application running at the same time should never have the same session ID.
inputFields.name: sessionID

types.name: SetSessionStatusInput

fields.description:
The number of seconds your application should wait before sending another setSessionStatus. If your application does
not call setSessionStatus again within roughly this duration, it will be assumed to have terminated unexpectedly and
its session status for this user will expire.
fields.name: setAgainInSeconds

fields.description: The modified user.
fields.name: user

types.description:
A squad stream represents a group of broadcasters that are streaming together.  When a squad
stream is live, viewers can opt to watch the streams of all its members together from a
single view.

Squad streams are created by a broadcaster who invites other broadcasters to participate.
Each broadcaster who accepts an invitation becomes a member of the squad stream and can also
invite other broadcasters to participate.  At the moment, a squad stream can have up to
four members and a broadcaster can only belong to a single squad stream.

A squad stream ends when all its members leave or stop streaming.

fields.description: The ID of the squad stream.
fields.name: id

fields.description: The invitations with the given status that have been sent by members to other users to join to squad stream.
fields.name: invitations

fields.name: members

fields.description: The owner can remove members from the squad stream.
fields.name: owner

fields.description: The current status of the squad stream.
fields.name: status

fields.description:
ThirdPartyPurchaseSKU is different from templateSKU since it represents the SKU of the exact item the
user will purchase. It is more expensive to retrieve purchaseSKU than templateSKU, so only
use purchaseSKU when the user has indicated they want to checkout. Use templateSKU on channel
page load to retrieve product information.

Will return an error if the user has no purchasable skus. Will return nil if not on a platform
with an external subscription product or if the country is not supported.
Uses Client-ID to determine platform information and IP address to determine location.
fields.name: thirdPartyPurchaseSKU

types.description:
TimetableEvent describes an event that comprises of a collection of closely related sub-events.
TimetableEvent would be good at representing:
  * A gaming event like "Awesome Games Done Quick 2018" which each run is its own piece of content that can
    be represented by a SegmentEvent
  * A conference like "TwitchCon 2017" where each panel is its own piece of content that can be represented
    by a SegmentEvent.

The URL or a URL template to the cover image for this event.
An optional width and height can be given to specify the dimension of the image in pixels.
If left unspecified, this field will be a URL template with {width} and {height} placeholders
that the client can replace to create a functional URL.
When width and height are given, this field is a full URL to the image.
The image is first scaled to maintain its aspect ratio, then cropped to fit the given dimensions.

types.description:
Tournament is an object that contains all information about a tournament
managed within Bits for a specific event tied to cheering.
NOTE: Should have been named CheeringTournament.

fields.name: id

fields.description:
The list of global milestones that can be claimed in the tournament.
For a given threshold, this milestone is reached when cheers from all users on the channel
is greater than or equal to the threshold. This unlocks a reward for all users who have cheered.
fields.name: progress

fields.description:
The list of rewards that are a part of the tournament. This is separated out into global, participant, and individual
rewards that can be claimed if the user is logged in.
fields.name: rewards

fields.description:
The list of individual milestones that can be claimed in the tournament.
for a given threshold, this milestone is reached when an individual user's total cheers in
the channel is greater than or equal to the threshold. This unlocks a reward
for the individual user who cheered.
fields.name: self

fields.description:
Leaderboard of all teams who have been cheered for in the tournament. This leaderboard contains how much each team
in the tournament was cheered for.
fields.name: teamLeaderboard

fields.description: The list of teams participating in the tournament.
fields.name: teams

types.description: Twitch user.

fields.description: Information about a user's connected accounts.
fields.name: accountConnections

fields.description:
An action that a user or session is performing. This field is null if the user is not friends with
the authenticated user.
fields.name: activity

fields.description: Ad Properties for the given user.
fields.name: adProperties

fields.description: The user's relationship with Amazon.
fields.name: amazon

fields.description: amazonMarketplaces returns a list of Amazon marketplaces in which this user is active in.
fields.name: amazonMarketplaces

fields.description:
AutoModProperties is a mapping of automod categories to levels, i.e. a user has indicated they want level 4, or
the highest level of moderation for profanity, but level 1 for everything else.
fields.name: autoModProperties

fields.description:
The list of channel that this user has configured to automatically host
when their channel is not streaming live. Users can only view their own
autohost channels.
fields.name: autohostChannels

fields.description:
Options and preferences for autohost behavior, including whether
autohosting is enabled at all and how to choose which channel to host.
Users can only view their own autohost settings.
fields.name: autohostSettings

fields.description:
An action that a user or session is performing. This field is null if the user is not friends with
the authenticated user.
fields.name: availability

fields.description:
The badges which are available for the authenticated user to select for use on another user's streams and videos if no channel-specific preference is set.
If no domain is not specified, all emote sets will be returned.
This is only returned if the request is authenticated by the same user whose email is requested.
fields.name: availableBadges

fields.description:
A list of this user's banned users.
A maximum of 100 users by most recent are returned
Only resolves for the authenticated user.
fields.name: bannedUsers

fields.description: A URL to the user's banner image.
fields.name: bannerImageURL

fields.description:
bitsBalance is the number of bits this user currently has available to spend.
If this isn't the `currentUser` or the user has been banned from using bits this will return null.
This field can only be requested if an OAuth token is supplied with the request.
fields.name: bitsBalance

fields.description:
bitsOffers is a list of the ways this user can obtain more bits.
If this isn't the `currentUser` or the user has been banned from using bits this will return null.
This field can only be requested if an OAuth token is supplied with the request.
fields.name: bitsOffers

fields.description:
BitsProductEligibility checks for a given user if they are eligible to purchase a given product from the associated
provider, quantity, and locale.
bitsProduct(id: ID!, provider: BitsProductProvider!, quantity: Int!, locale: String!): BitsProductEligibility!
bitsProducts is a list of bits products that a user is able to purchase.
Unlike bitsOffers, this does not return any pricing information, only information
about the purchaseable. A provider must be supplied, which is the payment platform
being currently used. An optional list of SKUs can be provided if we are looking up
a specific set of products for a user.
fields.name: bitsProducts

fields.description: Settings tied to a bits user.
fields.name: bitsUserSettings

fields.description:
bitsUserState dictates the state of the Bits user (new to Bits, existing Bits user, etc.)
If this isn't the `currentUser` or the user has been banned from using bits this will return null.
This field can only be requested if an OAuth token is supplied with the request.
fields.name: bitsUserState

fields.description: Resolves account information that Twitch has stored for a user's blizzard account information.
fields.name: blizzardAccount

fields.description: Get the blocked terms of a user.
fields.name: blockedTerms

fields.description: blockedUsers returns a list users that are restrained from directly communicating with this user.
fields.name: blockedUsers

fields.description: bounties is a list of bounty board bounties for this user.
fields.name: bounties

fields.description: bountyBoardSettings are settings and rules around the behavior of bounty boards for this user.
fields.name: bountyBoardSettings

fields.description: Badges that are displayed in chat during this user's broacasts or videos.
fields.name: broadcastBadges

fields.description: A User's broadcast settings that persists between streams.
fields.name: broadcastSettings

fields.description: A User's campaign properties for their channel.
fields.name: campaignProperties

fields.description:
The channel which belongs to the user. This is still deprecated for previous uses.
This should only be used for the multi-view experience.
fields.name: channel

fields.description: What other similar content are my viewers watching.
fields.name: channelAnalyticsContentOverlap

fields.description:
A user's channel feed.
No authorization required.  Returns even if channel feed is disabled in the UI.
fields.name: channelFeed

fields.description: Returns the list of chatrooms in the channel visible by the current user.
fields.name: channelRooms

fields.description: Hex color of the user's name in chat, e.g. "#ccaa44".
fields.name: chatColor

fields.description: chatSettings are settings and rules for chatting in this user's channel.
fields.name: chatSettings

fields.description: chatUISettings are settings for the user's chat UI.
fields.name: chatUISettings

fields.description:
cheer is the channel-specific cheer settings and current state.
Returns null if cheering isn't enabled for this channel.
fields.name: cheer

fields.description: The list of OAuth clients authorized by the current user.
fields.name: clientAuthorizations

fields.description:
A paginated list of clips featuring this user.
When criteria is not specified, the default values are used.
fields.name: clips

fields.description: A paginated list of collections (playlists) created by the user.
fields.name: collections

fields.description:
The company that the user belongs to.
Returns null if the user doesn't belong to a company.
fields.name: company

fields.description:
A list of Twitch crates in a user's inventory.
This is only returned if the request is authenticated by the same user who's email is requested.
fields.name: crates

fields.description: When the user created their account.
fields.name: createdAt

fields.description: A user-provided blurb describing themselves.
fields.name: description

fields.description: The directories the user is currently set to broadcast in.
fields.name: directories

fields.description:
Lists the chat badges that should be displayed by the user's display name in
features like chat and whispers. If a channelID is passed in, fetches the
display badges that user will have in that channel's context.
Includes the following badges:
- global authority (staff/admin/global mod)
- channel authority (broadcaster/mod, if channelID is set)
- subscriber (if channelID is set)
- channel selected (bits) or global selected (prime, turbo, ...).
fields.name: displayBadges

fields.description:
A user-styled version of their login.
For international users, this could be the user's login with localized characters.
fields.name: displayName

fields.description: A list of channel editors.
fields.name: editors

fields.description:
The user's email address.
This is only returned if the request is authenticated by the same user who's email is requested.
fields.name: email

fields.description:
The emote sets this user is entitled to use.
If no domains are specified, all emote sets will be returned.
If multiple domains are specified, emotes that belong to either domain are returned (OR).
If this user is not the current user, it returns nil and a "forbidden" error.
fields.name: emoteSets

fields.description: The channel's emoticon prefix settings.
fields.name: emoticonPrefix

fields.description:
Paginated list of leaf events that will or have run on theis user's channel.
This selects *all* leaves of all collections that this user might have assocated as well.
An optional criteria object can be given to specify the relevant time window that events should fall within, and
how the events are sorted.
NOTE: If no time window is given, this field will only contain upcoming events.
fields.name: eventLeaves

fields.description:
Paginated list of events that will or have run on this user's channel.
An optional criteria object can be given to specify the relevant time window that events should fall within, and
how the events are sorted.
NOTE: If no time window is given, this field will only contain upcoming events.
fields.name: events

fields.description:
A paginated list of user's all expired subscriptions.
Only resolves for the current user. Returns a forbidden error if requested for another user.
fields.name: expiredSubscriptions

fields.description:
Feature flags specific to this user.
This is only returned if the request is authenticated by the same user whose email is requested.
fields.name: featureFlags

fields.description:
A follow relationship between this user and the one which has the target ID or login.
Null if no relationship exists.
fields.name: follow

fields.description:
A list of communities this user is following, ordered by most viewers.
Only resolves for the authenticated user.
fields.name: followedCommunities

fields.description: Paginated list of events that this user is currently following.
fields.name: followedEvents

fields.description: Retrieves a list of games which the user is following.
fields.name: followedGames

fields.deprecationReason: This field is intended to be replaced as soon as an alternative is available.
fields.description:
A list of broadcasters this user follows, who are hosting other broadcasters.
Only resolves for the authenticated user.
fields.name: followedHosts

fields.deprecationReason: This field is intended to be replaced as soon as an alternative is available.
fields.description:
A list of live-streaming broadcasters this user is following.
Only resolves for the authenticated user.
fields.name: followedLiveUsers

fields.description:
Retrieves recent/popular VODs from the streamers you follow.
If this isn't the `currentUser` this will return null.
fields.name: followedVideos

fields.description: A paginated list of users which follow this user.
fields.name: followers

fields.description: A paginated list of users this user is following.
fields.name: follows

fields.description:
A list of this user's Twitch friends.
A maximum of 500 friends are returned, although most users have less than the maximum.
Only accessible if the user is authenticated with the `user_presence_friends_read` scope.
fields.name: friends

fields.description: Whether this user has Twitch Prime.

fields.description: Whether this user has Twitch Turbo.

fields.description: A curated list of suggested channels to host.

fields.description: Whether or not the user has verified their email address by clicking a link sent to their email.

fields.description: Whether or not the user can moderate any broadcast chat.

fields.description:
Whether or not the user is in good standing, granting automatic emote approval.

fields.description: Whether the user meets the GDPR compliance as per his/her country's minimum compliance age.

fields.description: Whether or not the user is moderator of a another user's channel.

fields.description: Whether or not the user is a site admininistrator.

fields.description: Whether or not the user is a Twitch staff member.

types.description:
UserSelfBitsBadge contains the current user's badge tier in a channel and progress toward the next tier.
NOTE: should probably have been named CurrentUserBitsBadge.

fields.description:
current is the highest bits chat badge the authenticated user has achieved in this channel.
If a badge tier is disabled after being earned it will still appear here until the next tier is earned.
If the user hasn't earned any bits badges yet this will be null.
fields.name: current

fields.description:
next is the next chat badge the authenticated user can earn in this channel.
If this is null then there are no higher tiers to earn.
fields.name: next

fields.description:
nextBits is the bits value of the next chat badge the authenticated user can earn in this channel.
If this is null then there are no higher tiers to earn.
fields.name: nextBits

fields.description:
progress is the fraction of the way the user is toward the next badge tier [0.0-1.0).
If `next` is null this will be zero.
fields.name: progress

fields.description: totalBits is the number of bits the authenticated user has used in this channel.
fields.name: totalBits

- global authority (staff/admin/global mod)
- channel authority (broadcaster/mod)
- subscriber
- channel selected (bits) or global selected (prime, turbo, ...).

For past broadcasts and uploads, this means nothing.

The URL to the thumbnail which should be displayed for the video.

fields.name: previewThumbnailURL

The time when the archive/highlight/upload was first ever available to public,
even if it is not currently public.

fields.description:
The reason a video is restricted if the given video is a restricted video.
For a video that is not restricted, this field can be null.
fields.name: restriction

fields.description: Either PRIVATE or PUBLIC.
fields.name: scope

fields.description: The authenticated user's relationship with this video.
fields.name: self

fields.description:
When broadcastType is:
- ARCHIVE: status goes from RECORDING to RECORDED.
- HIGHLIGHT: status goes from UNPROCESSED to RECORDED.
- UPLOAD: status goes from CREATED to UPLOADING, to PENDING_TRANSCODE, to RECORDED, or FAILED if anything goes wrong.
- PREMIERE_UPLOAD: status goes from CREATED to UPLOADING, to PENDING_TRANSCODE, to RECORDED, or FAILED if anything goes wrong.
- PAST_PREMIERE: status goes from RECORDING to RECORDED.
fields.name: status

fields.description: An array of tags describing the video. This field will be deprecated soon. Please use `Video.contentTag` instead.
fields.name: tags

fields.description:
A list of thumbnail URLs for the video, ordered by descending priority.
Owners can insert custom thumbnails into this list.
If either `height` or `width` are not given, a templated value (i.e. `{height}`, `{width}`) will be present in the URL instead.
fields.name: thumbnailURLs

fields.description:
For a scheduled video, the time when the video will be made available to the
public (the time when the scope will be automatically set to "public").

fields.name: viewableAt

types.description:
The user's shared availability while online.
A value of ONLINE (typically called invisibility) additionally means that the user's activity will not be shared
regardless of the isSharingActivity setting.
NOTE: Should have been named UserOnlineVisibility.
types.name: Visibility

types.description: A visibility type for the user.

enumValues.description:
An ONLINE visibility (default) will cause the user's availability to be inherited from their sessions -- Online if
they have at least one non-idle session, Away if they have only idle sessions, or Offline if they have no sessions.
enumValues.name: ONLINE

enumValues.description:
An AWAY visibility will cause the user to appear as Away if they have any sessions, regardless of idleness, or
Offline if they have no sessions.
enumValues.name: AWAY

enumValues.description:
A BUSY visibility will cause the user to appear as Busy if they have any sessions, regardless of idleness, or
Offline if they have no sessions.
enumValues.name: BUSY

enumValues.description:
An OFFLINE visibility (also called "invisible") will cause the user to appear as Offline always. It will also
implicitly turn off activity sharing.
enumValues.name: OFFLINE

types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior
in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or
skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information
to the executor.
types.name: __Directive

types.description:
A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a
__DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.
enumValues.name: QUERY

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.
enumValues.name: MUTATION

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.
enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.
enumValues.name: FIELD

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.
enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.
enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.
enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.
enumValues.name: SCHEMA

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.
enumValues.name: SCALAR

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.
enumValues.name: OBJECT

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.
enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.
enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.
enumValues.name: INTERFACE

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.
enumValues.name: UNION

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.
enumValues.name: ENUM

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.
enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.
enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT

enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.
enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION

types.name: __DirectiveLocation

types.description:
One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a
placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in
a JSON response as a string.
types.name: __EnumValue

types.description:
Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has
a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.
types.name: __Field

types.description:
Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an
InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and
optionally a default value.

fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.
fields.name: defaultValue

types.name: __InputValue

types.description:
A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all
available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for
query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.
fields.name: types

fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.
fields.name: queryType

fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.
fields.name: mutationType

fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.
fields.name: subscriptionType

fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.
fields.name: directives

types.name: __Schema

types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of
types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that
type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while
Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields
they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types
possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.
types.name: __Type

types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.
enumValues.name: SCALAR

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.
enumValues.name: OBJECT

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.
enumValues.name: INTERFACE

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.
enumValues.name: UNION

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.
enumValues.name: ENUM

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.
enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.
enumValues.name: LIST

enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.
enumValues.name: NON_NULL

types.name: __TypeKind
